summary: This is a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) policy manual (P6360.01) establishing comprehensive guidelines for pharmacy services within federal correctional institutions. It details staffing requirements, operational standards, procedures for medication dispensing and control, and specific protocols for handling DEA-controlled substances. This document is a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) Program Statement (P6360.01) detailing comprehensive policies and procedures for the management, dispensing, inventory, and security of controlled substances and other medications within federal correctional institutions. It outlines strict protocols for storage, auditing, administration, error reporting, and disposal to comply with DEA regulations. This is a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) policy document (P6360.01) titled 'Pharmacy Services', dated January 15, 2005. It outlines comprehensive procedures for medication management, error reporting, controlled substance handling (including methadone), and patient counseling within federal correctional institutions. It is a standard operating procedure and does not contain specific case information related to Jeffrey Epstein.

keyFacts: The document is a formal BOP policy (P6360.01) dated January 15, 2005, governing all pharmacy operations in federal prisons.
It establishes strict security protocols for controlled substances, including limited key access, mandatory inventories, and the use of vaults or safes.
The policy mandates that each institution's pharmacy be directed by a qualified Chief Pharmacist who is the responsible authority for all DEA-controlled substances.
It references the use of automated medication administration systems (e.g., Pyxis, SureMed) which can replace manual shift inventories and proof-of-use sheets for controlled substances.

The policy outlines a structured Pharmacy and Therapeutics (P&T) Committee system that must meet quarterly to manage the institution's drug formulary and review medication errors and adverse reactions.
The document is a formal BOP policy (P6360.01) establishing strict, detailed procedures for handling controlled substances in federal prisons, dated January 15, 2005.
It mandates secure storage of controlled substances in vaults, safes, or locked cabinets, and requires a biennial inventory to be conducted on a federally mandated schedule.
Procedures are defined for reporting theft or loss of controlled substances to the DEA using Form 106, and for quarterly audits by a designated inventory team.
The policy specifies that medications, especially controlled substances, must be administered under direct observation to prevent inmates from 'cheeking' or diverting them.
It establishes a formal Medication Error Program, categorizing different types of errors and emphasizing a blame-free, systems-focused approach to quality improvement.
This document is Bureau of Prisons Program Statement P6360.01 on 'Pharmacy Services', effective January 15, 2005.
It details strict protocols for medication use, error reporting (with severity levels 0-6), and the control of needles and syringes within BOP facilities.
It specifies regulations for methadone use, limiting it to three approved uses: treatment of opiate-addicted pregnant inmates, detoxification, and treatment of severe pain.
The policy mandates procedures for inmate transfer and release, including supplying medications for up to 90 days for transfers to Community Corrections Centers (CCC).
The document is signed by Harley G. Lappin, who was the Director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons at the time.
